Amycolatopsis rubida is a species of actinobacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Japan. It is a Gram-positive, aerobic, and non-spore-forming bacterium. Cells of A. rubida are typically rod-shaped and can form branched, mycelium-like structures.

The distinctive feature of this species is its ability to produce a reddish-pink pigment, which is likely due to the production of carotenoid compounds. This pigmentation is the basis for the species name "rubida," which means "reddish" in Latin.

Amycolatopsis rubida is considered a slow-growing bacterium and can thrive in a range of environmental conditions, including moderate temperatures and slightly acidic pH levels. It is known to be capable of degrading various natural polymers, such as cellulose and hemicellulose, which suggests a potential role in the recycling of organic matter in soil ecosystems.

While the specific ecological functions and biotechnological applications of A. rubida are still being investigated, its unique pigmentation and metabolic capabilities make it an interesting subject for further study in the field of microbiology.
